which parts of this you'd like to use in your projects so we'll start off with SAS uh SAS is
something that I'm a real big fan of still uh it is a preprocessor that lets you do additional things with CSS code
that are not part of the current CSS spec SAS has been around for quite some
time now uh it lets you do things that CSS doesn't normally do one of the
things that CSS has now but didn't back a few years ago is have
variables and variables are extremely important to writing clean code they let
you reuse very reuse values over and over again and it just makes things so
much easier they've added a lot of module systems and things to SAS and SAS originally was written in
JavaScript or sorry Ruby and over the years that has evolved as well it is now
written in Dart now and one of the things that people used to give SAS a hard time over is the
compilation speed and that was the fact that it was written in these other languages and now that it's written in
Dart is extremely fast at compiling your SAS code into CSS
so if you have an application that you want to write a theme that kind of stretches across the entire app and you
want to use variables to control things maybe you want to have a light and dark theme I actually have an example of what
something like that might look like in the presentation itself like I said this is kind of a live demo of things that
are possible when you use these type of tools maybe you want to implement something that you can easily swap out a
couple values and change the entire theme of the app with so you can do that in SAS also show you
how to do this in regular CSS now that we've got tools to do that in the
language this also lets you break your CSS into modules it makes them much easier to use
and reuse so if you want to share pieces of CSS code across multiple projects SAS
lets you do that as well also if you're using bootstrap SAS is
optional now but in previous versions of bootstrap you were essentially using
Code that was built by using SAS and if you added SAS to your pipeline you could
you could trim down the amount of CSS code that was generated and only pick
the things out of the framework that really you were using in your project and minimize the bundles that you ship
to your your customers it's also great for styling things that
are not Blazer components because Blazer we'll talk about CSS isolation in a few minutes but there are things inside of
your app that may not be actual Razer components and you want to use regular CSS to style those things and you can
Elevate that CSS by using SAS
installing SAS is actually something that I think a lot of people get confused by when they start working on a
Blazer project because a lot of the SAS documentation that you see when you start searching on the web pertains to
things that use webpack and then node way of doing things so the JavaScript
way of building applications we're using things like webpack and some sort of

we don't really have anything dedicated to Blazer in this space so you see a lot of npm install and scripting and

now you have SAS available on your system and then you just run it

and you can have SAS compile as your project compiles so this can be super handy

so let's talk about CSS isolation next this is a very Blazer specific thing now all Frameworks uh modern web Frameworks
tend to have something like it and Blazer kind of gets influence from other things sometimes and we have CSS
isolation inside of Blazer now and what it allows us to do
is scope specific style sheets to components so we're actually marrying up a style
sheet with a component and what this does is it helps us um
work with our style sheets where they are attached to a component so if we
remove that component from a project then it also gets removed from the pro
the style sheet gets removed from the project as well it also helps with Collision so we don't accidentally
override styles on other components within that system so it manages
conflicts with other components and their style sheets
and the way it works is actually pretty clever and it involves the compiler so when we write a component the example on
the left hand side will have some sort of markup in that component and a matching style that gets applied to it
so in this example we just have an H1 whatever the contents are don't really matter here but we're going to write a
CSS selector to attach to that H1 tag
now the compiler is going to actually generate a unique identifier
and attach an attribute with that unique identifier on it and it will do the same thing for the
CSS file that's associated with that component so your output HTML and CSS by
the.net compiler is going to be an H1 tag with this specific attribute on it
and then your CSS code will have a selector that matches that very highly
specific CSS selector and what this does is it makes it so you can't accidentally write CSS that will
override that style is nearly impossible to override that you can do it on purpose if you try hard
enough but the compiler can generate a different good and that's going to end
up breaking that forced style override so this this will help if you really
want to lock down a style where you don't want other developers going in and muddying up the CSS code that you wrote
um I've been on projects where you kind of open the end of your CSS file and at
the very bottom there's a bunch of selectors that end in a bang important
where somebody's tried to override something higher up in the system and then when you kind of hit that plateau
of uh CSS code there's really no going back so this prevents those type of
things from happening or you've got your CSS code compartmentalized with your
components and then you've got this protection from overriding things by accident and having
those CSS collisions now I I do have kind of some
reservations with this as well because CSS isolation actually implies
an anti-pattern so CSS is cascading style sheets and if
we isolate it then we've kind of removed the Cascade from those style sheets
so it does come with some opinions Alyssa agrees in the back
um so it does come with some opinions so if you're creating components that you need
to control this style very strictly it's going to help you but if you need flexibility it's going to then hamper
what you're trying to do and that's what we'll talk about in the next segment is how to kind of manage that scope so this
is very narrow scoped CSS so we're only scoping that CSS to the component
so there's some general rules that I've got here we will go through every single one of them but I'll pick out some of
the important ones um like use this when that style is very
specific to that very component so if you're writing an overall theme for your application
then you probably want to put that code in something like SAS or just a general style sheet something that's very well
organized but is accessible by all components but if it's very specific to
that component then it can do very well in CSS isolation
um you might want to use a kind of a
traditional CSS class or css file if you're going to be sharing this uh
component to lots of users because you want them to be able to control what
that component looks like uh if they they your consumer is going to be doing any kind of customization then you might
not want to isolate those things do try to use it new projects see what
you think of it um see if some of these techniques work for
the projects that you're working on but don't go to in a project that's already
constructed and works well and isn't broken and try to add you know rewrite
the entire thing in CSS isolation because you learned it today like use your time wisely if it's not broke don't
fix it another feature of CSS isolation is the
Deep selector so you'll run into this on occasion where you have a parent-child
relationship you have two components that are nested inside one another and you need to influence the style of
that child component so in the example here we've got kind of
a a parent component that has this child underneath and when we render that child
component we want to style uh the h2 tag in there from the parent component
so in that component I have an H1 tag and then I also have our H1 selector and
I also have this deep double colon deep H2 selector what that means it's going
to escape from that CSS isolation by a
level and let me style the component that is nested underneath
now my tip here is if you have a lot of deep selectors in your component
and I'm talking you know maybe two three four you start seeing a pattern here that's going to give you a clue that you
need some abstraction instead of using the Deep selector you probably have another component that needs to be taken
out and put in its own file so I've run into that a few times I'm like this
parent keeps influencing the style of all these children components or this
children each you know all the HTML and the child component there's actually multiple components that need to be
broken out and put in their own files and isolate it as well
so you can find some code smells with CSS isolation like I said with CSS isolation you're
kind of working against CSS where traditional CSS gives you the
ability to theme the overall uh you know style of the application
where CSS isolation is per component we're kind of locking this down and we
don't want anything to influence the look and feel of that component and I like to set up this slide with a
kind of a sliding scale of customization where we want to find the right fit for
what we're developing because we need to tailor it to who's consuming the code
we're writing so for us at progress we make the telework UI for Blazer components it's
like a hundred components that we're going to give or we're going to sell to many many customers that have their own
Brands their own themes and they want to customize these things completely so we
don't want to isolate any of that CSS code we want them to be able to customize that as they see fit
so we've kind of got that first scenario where we have Global customization so we're at the very end of the spectrum
here we want uh the end developer to be able to do whatever they'd like with the
style of these components um and we use see it we use SAS for ours
so we actually have uh SAS code that's very easy to go plugins and new values
and re-theme the entire Suite of components and we even have a third additional tool called theme Builder
that you can go in and use a wysiwyg type of Editor to actually theme all the
components and that will generate the CSS and SAS code for you so that's that's kind of the extreme end there and
then the other extreme end uh the third one is you know minimal customization we
have this very strict brand at our company and we don't want uh you know we
want developer a to write the CSS code with a designer or or another team we
don't want developer B to ever touch that we don't want them to accidentally override anything or we don't want
somebody going rogue and using their own colors Etc uh so there's that minimal customization
where we want to lock everything down and then there's kind of a nice
balanced area that you can get into and that's what I want to really show you today is how you can use some additional
techniques to make it where you can pick the spectrum that you want to be on do
you want more Global customization or do you want to be more on the minimal

you've gone with this minimal customization your company gets acquired and now you have a new brand and you're

something crazy like that so there's a few things that can help
